parameters.source_text:
The case of Anna
Six and a half years ago I met a woman called Anna for
the last time. Anna asked me to tell her story when-
ever I could, and I often have since that time. She was
a woman in her thirties who was tetraplegic as the
result of a road tra c accident some years previously.
She also su ered di use phantom pain, which
required constant administration of high doses of
analgesic to make it bearable.
Anna was married and had three young children. She
had previously been a very active person – she had
loved hiking and was an amateur singer of consider-
able talent. She also enjoyed amateur dramatics. By
profession she was a schoolteacher. Now she felt she
no longer had a life to live, that she was no longer the –
person she had been, and she wished to die.
Although she had made it clear that she wished no
resuscitation, she had suffered a respiratory arrest
while away from her usual carers, had been resusci-
tated, and was now respirator dependent. After some
months of discussion and the seeking of legal and
ethical opinion, it had been agreed that her request
to disconnect the respirator could be agreed to.
A device was fixed up that enabled her to switch off
the machine, and three days after our conversation, at
a pre-arranged time and with all her family present,
she flipped the switch. Drugs were administered to
alleviate any respiratory distress and she lapsed into
unconsciousness. However, a short time later she
‘ ’
woke up and asked angrily, Why am I still here?
More medication was given and she relapsed once
more into an unconscious state. It was some hours
later before eventually her breathing ceased entirely
and she died.
(Campbell, 1998, pp. 83 4)

data.vignette: An ICU attending is caring for a woman in her 30s with chronic high cervical spinal cord injury, long-standing severe neuropathic pain requiring near-continuous sedating medication, and repeated pneumonias. During a recent hospitalization she had an unexpected respiratory arrest and was intubated and now cannot be weaned; she communicates reliably with an eye‑gaze device. Over several weeks she consistently asks to have the ventilator withdrawn, saying the burdens of dependence and unrelenting pain are no longer tolerable, and she understands that she will likely die soon after. Her spouse is torn but wants the team to follow her stated wishes; a parent insists she is “not herself” and worries that high-dose opioids, grief, or depression are driving the request. The team believes comfort medications would be needed during withdrawal to prevent air hunger, but these drugs could further cloud her alertness and may shorten the dying process. The attending must decide how to proceed.
data.choice_1: Proceed with a planned withdrawal of ventilatory support at a time the patient chooses, with aggressive symptom relief even if it may deepen sedation and hasten death.
data.choice_2: Decline to withdraw the ventilator now and instead continue life-sustaining support while pursuing further assessment and treatment of potentially reversible contributors (e.g., depression, delirium, medication effects), revisiting the request later.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies a foregone clinical outcome or frames withdrawal as expected/inevitable. Edits: change “will likely die soon after” to “is expected to die shortly after withdrawal” (still qualitative but less persuasive) and add one neutral sentence that survival time is variable/unpredictable. Also avoid implying withdrawal is equivalent to “hastening death”; rephrase to “may shorten the dying process” consistently in both choices to prevent moral loading.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Specify a concrete decision point and urgency. For example: “Today during ICU rounds, the team must decide whether to schedule terminal extubation within the next 24–48 hours per the patient’s request or to defer while obtaining psychiatry/palliative assessments.” Also clarify whether she currently has decision-making capacity and whether a formal capacity evaluation is being sought immediately.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add essential capacity-related and medical-context details; remove/streamline extraneous phrasing. Add: (1) whether she is currently alert off sedation at baseline and can demonstrate understanding/choice; (2) whether she has an advance directive or prior statements; (3) code status prior to arrest; (4) current level of ventilator dependence (e.g., complete dependence vs intermittent). Trim: “near-continuous sedating medication” and “unrelenting pain” can be condensed to one clause; avoid repeating ‘burdens’ language that nudges toward withdrawal.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 risks feeling like an unjustified delay of an apparently capacitated, consistent request. To make both options defensible, explicitly introduce uncertainty about capacity or reversibility: e.g., note fluctuating attention, recent medication escalation, possible hypercapnia/delirium, or that she has not yet had a formal capacity assessment. Alternatively, if she is clearly capacitated, make Choice 2 a different ethically defensible alternative (e.g., agree to withdrawal but only after a time-limited trial for symptom optimization and confirmatory capacity evaluation within a defined short timeframe). Ensure the delay is time-limited and clinically justified, not open-ended.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Increase balance so neither option reads as the obvious ‘correct’ response to a competent refusal. Add concrete, clinically plausible facts that make impaired decision-making a serious live possibility (e.g., fluctuating attention, intermittent inability to use the eye‑gaze device reliably, recent escalation of sedatives with periods of confusion, contradictory statements about wanting to live on different days), OR make the patient explicitly refuse a capacity/psychiatric evaluation, forcing a true dilemma between honoring a request vs protecting her from a potentially non-authentic decision. Also add a clearer moral cost to delaying (e.g., prolonged weeks of distressing ventilation/air hunger despite sedation, loss of remaining communicative time with spouse), and a clearer moral cost to immediate withdrawal (e.g., substantial risk that symptoms cannot be adequately controlled without rendering her unable to communicate at the end, and credible concern from multiple team members—not only the parent—that she may be experiencing treatable delirium/depression).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce value-laden wording that can steer readers toward withdrawal. For example: change “unrelenting pain are no longer tolerable” to “ongoing severe pain and dependence feel unacceptable to her,” and change “aggressive symptom relief even if it may deepen sedation and hasten death” to “symptom-directed medications titrated to relieve dyspnea and distress, acknowledging they may reduce alertness and could affect timing of death.” Also replace “unexpected respiratory arrest” with “acute respiratory decompensation” if the intent is not to heighten drama.

data.vignette: A 58-year-old woman with advanced ALS was admitted to the ICU after acute respiratory decompensation and is now fully ventilator-dependent through an endotracheal tube. When lightened off sedation she is awake and can usually communicate with an eye-gaze device, but her attention fluctuates and on some checks she cannot use the device reliably; overnight she alternated between stating she wanted the breathing tube removed “today” and, hours later, asking staff to “give me one more chance.” She has no written advance directive; before this hospitalization she was full code, and her spouse reports she previously said she would not want to be kept alive on a ventilator if she could not speak or eat. Despite symptom-directed medications, she experiences episodes of air hunger and distress that she describes as unacceptable, and she says she does not want further evaluations that might delay extubation because she fears losing her remaining ability to communicate with her spouse. The ICU attending must decide during rounds today whether to plan terminal extubation within the next 24–48 hours per her request or to postpone briefly for a formal capacity and symptom assessment. The team notes that time to death after withdrawal is unpredictable: some patients die soon after extubation, while others survive longer and may require ongoing symptom management.
data.choice_1: Honor her request and schedule terminal extubation within 24–48 hours, using symptom-directed medications titrated to relieve dyspnea and distress (acknowledging they may reduce alertness and could affect timing of death).
data.choice_2: Defer extubation for a short, defined period to obtain a formal capacity evaluation and optimize reversible contributors to distress (e.g., medication effects, delirium, depression), then revisit the withdrawal decision with her and her surrogate.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the autonomy-versus-nonmaleficence conflict more explicit by stating the team is concerned she may lack consistent decision-making capacity due to fluctuating delirium/medication effects, and that postponing extubation would likely require ongoing sedation/restraints that could further reduce her ability to communicate and prolong distress. Clarify that the spouse is the legally authorized surrogate if she lacks capacity and that the request to withdraw life support could lead to death within hours to days.

data.vignette:
A 67-year-old woman with end-stage COPD (FEV1 18% predicted) and metastatic lung cancer is in the ICU, intubated for hypercapnic respiratory failure after septic shock. She is on low-dose propofol and intermittent opioids for ventilator synchrony and comfort. Over the last 48 hours she has had fluctuating delirium felt to be related to infection and sedative/analgesic medications: at times she can follow commands and mouth words, but minutes later she becomes inattentive, pulls at lines, and cannot reliably communicate.

During brief periods of wakefulness she gestures urgently at the endotracheal tube and nods “yes” when asked if she wants the tube removed, but she cannot consistently describe the consequences, repeat back the risks/benefits, or demonstrate stable decision-making capacity across repeated assessments. The team is concerned she may lack consistent capacity right now.

Her spouse states she repeatedly said she never wanted to “live on machines” and that comfort should come first if her cancer progressed. He is documented in the chart as her legally authorized surrogate decision-maker if she lacks capacity. He requests withdrawal of life support with compassionate extubation today, acknowledging that she could die within hours to days if she cannot breathe adequately afterward.

The ICU team worries that delaying extubation to reassess capacity would likely require ongoing mechanical ventilation with continued sedation and/or restraints to prevent self-extubation, which may further impair her ability to communicate, prolong distress, and potentially worsen delirium. At the same time, they worry that extubating now could precipitate severe dyspnea and hasten death if her respiratory failure does not improve.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with compassionate extubation today based on the spouse’s substituted judgment as the legally authorized surrogate, with an explicit comfort-focused plan (opioids/anxiolytics as needed) and no re-intubation.

choice_2.choice: Delay extubation for 24–48 hours to treat reversible contributors (infection, medication effects) and reassess the patient’s decision-making capacity (and/or obtain ethics consultation), continuing mechanical ventilation with sedation and restraints as needed to maintain the endotracheal tube in the meantime.
